PM

Hmm

PM

Uncertain Outlook Prompts Chair Yellen to Delay Fed Hike Again
Following the slowest pace of monthly payroll gains since 2011, Chair Yellen's remarks today modified her recently articulated guidance about policy rates. She pointed to the disappointing payroll growth as one reason for “considerable and unavoidable uncertainty” surrounding the outlook for the domestic economy. Before the release of the May employment report, Chair Yellen's May 27 Q&A session at Harvard noted that it would be appropriate to resume normalizing rates “probably, in the coming months.” Today, Yellen dropped “coming months” and stated only that further normalization would “probably be appropriate.”

Chair Yellen sided with the dovish views of fellow Board members, and bolstered our view that September is a more likely time for the next rate hike than June or July. Whether or not the Fed resumes rate normalization soon hinges on their assessment of the May slowdown; is the slower payroll growth more pervasive, or an isolated temporary blip?

PM

This is William Lee, Citi

11:09 am
PM

May Payrolls Provide Rationale For Delay
With the unemployment rate at or below most estimates of the natural rate, especially after a cyclical rebound in the participation rate, most would agree that monthly payroll growth in excess of 200K is not sustainable. Indeed, the Fed and we had been expecting payroll growth to a slow gradually. However, the May payroll decline to 38K was surprisingly sharp (even if we include back the 35K telecom strikers) and broad-based. Together with subdued wage growth, the latest labor market report raises the possibility that the slow pace of employment growth may reflect a broader slowdown in the US economy, rather than a limited supply of workers.

Our judgment is that without corroborating evidence of a more widespread pause, the May labor market slowdown is likely a temporary blip, possibly reflecting the tepid GDP growth recorded in the last quarter (see US Economics Flash: Payrolls Grossly Disappoint; Market June/July Fed Rate Hike Expectations Plummet).

PM

Despite these labor-market concerns, Chair Yellen expects “the positive forces supporting employment growth and higher inflation to continue to outweigh the negative ones.” But while Yellen’s outlook is balanced, an asymmetry is introduced in policy making by the reduced ability of monetary policy to respond to negative shocks to the outlook. As often noted by FOMC doves (such as Governor Brainard), this situation calls for a risk-management approach toward formulating monetary policy. Such an approach would raise the preference for inaction when uncertainty rises. Delayed rate normalization would be appropriate even with a “cautiously optimistic” outlook.

For now, Chair Yellen seems to agree with most other FOMC participants expressing views after the May payroll report (e.g., Brainard (Governor), Rosengren (Boston), Evans (Chicago) and Lockhart). They have all stated a desire to take a wait and see approach following the report. Cleveland Fed President Mester struck a more hawkish note, emphasizing that one data point left her medium term outlook little changed. Chair Yellen noted in the Q&A session today that she seeks to build a consensus – and the most recent data should make the case for inaction a much easier sell to the hawks.

PM

Prospective Global Events Point to Delaying Normalization
In addition to the domestic data, Chair Yellen cited two external threats that could derail the timing of the next rate increase. We have noted in the past that either of these could derail a planned Fed hike, even if the domestic data looks a bit firmer

China – Volatility in Chinese currency and equity markets was enough to prevent the Fed from hiking in September 2015. Recently policy stimulus has stabilized the economy and financial markets, but another bout of volatility could cause the Fed to pause.

Brexit – FOMC participants are perhaps most in agreement on the need to take into account Brexit risk in deciding whether or not to hike. As Fed Governor Tarullo recently emphasized, it is not so much the economic outcome of Brexit but rather financial market volatility induced by the referendum that affects near-term rate hikes. Recent polling showing a thin spread between “leave” and “remain” camps (together with uneven labor market data) makes a pre-referendum June hike very unlikely in our view. Regardless of the referendum outcome, if market volatility continues into July, the FOMC would be unlikely to move.

11:10 am
PM

this suddenly turns rather....er...

PM

Concluding Thoughts: Chair Yellen Gazes Again Upon Her Guiding R-Star

PM

While much market attention is focused on the exact timing of the next rate hike, a more important question for markets, and the Fed, is the subsequent pace of normalization and the terminal policy rate. Echoing Governor Brainard’s speech from Friday, Chair Yellen emphasized that the neutral policy rate remains at historically low levels, and will stay low so long as growth and inflation remain tepid. If the policy rate is below the neutral rate, the FOMC would be maintaining an accommodative policy stance.

A persistently lower neutral rate implies less near-term urgency to hike, as well as a subsequently shallower and more gradual policy normalization trajectory. With the tepid, albeit above-potential, growth forecast by the FOMC and ourselves over the next two years, it is unlikely that the neutral rate would rise fast enough to warrant the three to four rate increases advocated by the more hawkish FOMC participants this year.

Until the heightened uncertainty Chair Yellen noted today dissipates, we believe the FOMC will stay on hold: September remains our most likely time for the next rate increase. With Chair Yellen's continued use of the neutral real rate (R-star) as a guide for setting policy, we maintain our trajectory of one rate hike this year and two in 2017. Of course, if projected growth or inflation were to be revised higher, we would raise the path for rate increases as well.

BE

Key points:

· Synergy target increased to $4.5bn by 2018, from $3.5bn previously with $4bn to be reached in 2017.

· Capex to be in a range of $25-30bn each year to 2020, in line with our forecast.

· Potential for $20-$25bn of organic free cash flow around the end of the decade in a $60/bl oil price environment, which implies $50bn of operating cash flow and is in line with our forecast.

· Potential for a 10% RoACE around the end of the decade above our forecast of 8%.

· 2016 capex reduced to $29bn, from $30bn previously.

· Asset sales are expected to be $30bn for 2016-18, in line with previous guidance. Shell has earmarked 10% of oil and gas production for disposal including 5-10 country exits.

· Significant progress on the first $6-8bn of this program is expected to be made in 2016.

· $40bn opex run-rate to be reached this year in-line with indications at the 1Q results.

· Chemicals & deepwater are now Shell’s growth priorities with Integrated Gas reaching critical mass where the pace of investment will slow.

· Shell to give priority to growth projects such that free cash flow for these may be negative at the lower end of the cycle.

· New project start-ups since end 2014 should contribute $10bn of annual cash flow by 2018 at $60/bl.

· Final Investment decision announced on a new 1.5mtpa polyethylene plant in Pennsylvania which will use natural gas from shales production as feedstock and will increase Shell’s ethylene capacity by 30% to 8mtpa.

· Shell’s deepwater production could double to some 900kboe/d in 2020 vs 450kboe/d in 2015.

· Investment in future opportunities including shale & new energies to remain low with free cash flow likely negative and returns low for some time.

BE

And how they read it all ..........

11:15 am
BE

Royal Dutch Shell’s first capital markets day post the BG deal is incrementally positive for the stock in our view. Although there are many details given within the release, the main focus for us is on the ability of the combined company to generate free cash flow and pay a dividend that the market still seems reluctant to believe is sustainable. The statement this morning should be reassuring in this regard with the priorities of debt reduction and dividend payments remaining unchanged. Indeed RDS indicated that organic free cash flow could reach $20-25bn by 2020. This compares with a dividend payment of c$15bn and given the sensitivity of the group to changing oil prices suggests a cashflow break-even of $40-50/bl. In terms of new guidance capex expectations for 2016 have been reduced to $29bn with the long run range is given as $25-30bn with the decision on what level of capex to spend balanced against progress made on the share buyback plan, particularly given Shell’s ambition in the title of its statement this morning to “create a world class investment case”. The synergy number has been increased by $1bn to $4.5bn of which $3bn is opex related. This is lower than we were looking for, but does appear to be a definitional issue given the improvement expected in underlying opex is in-line with our assumptions. Overall the Shell release this morning sets out the case for resilient free cash flow generation in a reasonable oil price environment with a re-shaped and more profitable business. Given this, we see the 7.6% dividend yield that Shell offers as inconsistent with the financial performance of the company. We continue to see the investment case for Royal Dutch Shell as compelling and rate the stock Overweight with a 2450p price target.

BE

SocGen saying the same. Sensible and reassuring.

BE

Shell message at the CMD were sensible and reassuring, portraying a visible path
U
to its target of growing per-share free cash flow and returns. (1) 2016 capital investment is
M
reduced to $29bn (from an original $33bn, guided to $30bn last month); as explained in the
note seen here, that translates into cash flow capex of around $25-27bn. (2) Shell provided L
visibility and aligned itself to peers by presenting for the first time ever its intended long-term I
capex plan for 2016-20 of $25-30bn p.a., depending on oil prices. (3) With a c.50% step-up in S
LNG capacity post BG deal, it recognises the gas business now has “critical mass” – T
meaning no new LNG growth investments and a shift in focus to free cash flow. (4) Shell is
raising the BG synergies further, by 30% to $4.5bn (and by 80% compared to the original
$2.5bn in April 2015). We originally estimated last year that $5bn in BG synergies was
feasible; we thus view the $4.5bn synergy target as realistic and expect most of it ($4bn) to
be delivered quickly, in 2017. (5) Operating costs are to be reduced to $40bn this year, 20%
below the 2014 level with potential for further reductions. (6) Shell provides guidance on
organic free cash flow at $60/bbl: this excludes disposals and is before dividends and the aim
is for $20-25bn p.a. of FCF by 2020 (under $60/bbl oil), with a 10% ROACE; with oil at
$90/bbl in 2013-15, Shell’s FCF was only $12bn and RoACE only 8%. The cost of today’s
cash dividend is $15bn; so at $60/bbl Shell looks to be paying down debt – which is also
reassuring. (7) Asset sales remain unchanged at $30bn in 2016-18, but guidance for $6-8bn
in 2016 provides visibility and is well above expectations. Shell has apparently earmarked
10% of its oil and gas production for disposals, including 5-10 country exits. As we
anticipated, the CEO states disposals are “value driven”, not time driven.

So, whilst far from a bumper month for the retail trade it is welcome news that ‎the BRC-KPMG sales monitor is positive for May on both a like-for-like (LFL) and total sales basis in the UK. Accordingly, same-store sales rose by 0.5% versus a three-month (3M) average of minus 0.4% whilst total revenues rose by 1.4% versus a 0.5% 3M average. The comparative for May on a LFL basis was flat whilst for total sales it was 1.1%.

Rebound in Clothing sales, relinquishing furniture as the top performing category, and fueling non-food LFL of +0.9%. This was supported by strong sales in seasonal merchandise given the good weather, and comes as a relief after weak trends in the preceding 6 months. BRC's commentary suggests varied promotional stance as some clothing retailers ran more promotions than others while in footwear, there was a preference for short flash sales over longer mid-seasonal offers (clothing deflation stepped up to -7.5% vs -7.1% in April, -6.7% in Q1 and -6.3% in 2015). In contrast home-related spend slowed given the combination of tough comparables, negative calendar impact and Brexit uncertainties.

Non-food online sales accelerated to +13.7% in May after +6.6% in April, 11.7% in Q1 and 12.7% in 2015 as a whole. Online penetration of greater than 21% and contribution of 2.6% is the highest recorded by the BRC (excluding Black Friday and January sales skew).

Food sales were marginally better with estimated LFL of +0.1% after -0.1% in April and -2.1% in Q1. Food prices have continued to oscillate around the 0% mark since mid-2015 (though we believe the big four are currently seeing food deflation of between 1% to 3%) which remains an unhelpful feature.

BE

BE

Here's Deutsche.

BE

he new CEO of the subsidiary is Matthew Crummack, who was CEO of
lastminute.com from 2011 until its takeover in 2015. Given his deep experience
of digital platforms, our sense is that he is strongly placed to take the operation
forward. As a reminder, esure bought the 50% which it did not originally own
in mid-2015 for £95m. Its target is to at least double its EBIT from an
underlying £25m in 2014 to £50m in 2019. Our own forecasts build in a slightly
slower trajectory, to almost £30m in 2016e (in line with management’s
guidance, which has been maintained), rising to £43.6m by 2019e.

11:44 am
BE

Without wanting to pre-judge the outcome of the strategic review, at the very
least we see it as a likely positive for how esure is valued. To put it in
perspective, our forecasts in 2017e-2018e for Gocompare are equivalent to
£27m and £32m post-tax, or 26% and 27% respectively of operating earnings.
Moneysupermarket (309p, Not Covered), which is its main listed peer, trades
at 18.4x and 17.0x earnings in these two years respectively, based on the
consensus adjusted EPS estimates on its own website. Even if we were to
apply a 20% discount to these, the implied valuation on Gocompare would be
£395m-£430m, equivalent to 34%-37% of esure’s current market
capitalisation. Put another way, if Gocompare were valued in a demerger at
£395m, we estimate that the implied PE on the remaining underwriting
operations would reduce from a current 11.7x 2017e (and 10.4x 2018e) to
10.6x and 9.5x respectively... equivalent to a c.10% change in the rating.

BE

Clearly, much depends on both the extent to which Gocompare can deliver on
management’s five-year outlook, and the price at which it could trade at – if
indeed management were to demerge it. As a guide to sensitivities, every 10%
change in the value we might attach to Gocompare is equivalent to 3.5% of the
current market cap. Alternatively, it would have to trade at a 37% discount to
Moneysupermarket in 2017e to leave the implied PE on the remaining earnings
unchanged.
Finally, we note that a demerger of Gocompare – if it were to happen – would
have only a limited impact on esure’s solvency position, given the former’s
minimal tangible book value.

BE

And Barclays.

11:44 am
BE

Why now? 12 months earlier than we would have expected

We had assumed that esure would seek to unlock value in gocompare if the market did not give it credit for the asset in its valuation, but we assumed a potential demerger / IPO would be in 12 to 18 months, as the company worked towards its 2019 target of “at least £50m of earnings”. Today’s announcement is therefore earlier than we would have expected. This could be purely because the company is being opportunistic, benefiting from the reinvigorated gocompare.com advertising campaign. The founder and Chairman of esure, Peter Wood, remains the largest shareholder of esure with 30% of the stock, and is likely to monetize his holding at some point and therefore would naturally seek to maximize the value of his holding before selling his stake. It could also have been the carrot to entice Matthew Crummack to join as the new CEO of gocompare. Mr. Crummack’s background as the CEO of lastminute.com will be beneficial in the next stage of gocompare’s development. The current CEO, Jon Morrell, had an insurance broking background.

BE

Has esure doubled the value of gocompare in one year?

Esure acquired the 50% of gocompare it did not own for £95m, funded by debt and valuing the franchise at £190m. The deal completed in April 2015. The transaction diversified earnings, increased capital levels on both Solvency 1 and Solvency 2, and was earnings accretive from year one on a cash basis. The valuation of the transaction was equivalent to c50% of the valuation of the franchise based on the Moneysupermarket multiple at the time. Did the company double the value of the franchise in 12 months? Is gocompare worth the MONY multiple?

Esure did get a good deal on the asset, as it was effectively the only buyer as it held a veto over any other potential buyer. The company has also reinvigorated the brand, and the benefit of full ownership and management has already started to show progress. MONY does have higher margins and is more diversified away from motor insurance, but we believe esure will follow the MONY roadmap and diversify gocompare’s franchise in order to grow revenues, which will allow them to continue to invest in marketing spend. If gocompare delivers on its £50m earnings target by 2019, that would infer a profit CAGR of 25% from 2015 to 2019E, ahead of MONY’s c9% CAGR. So although GC is less diversified and further behind in delivering on the non motor verticals (and arguably lower multiple), if it does have higher growth as it catches up, arguably justifying a similar multiple to MONY.

BE

Gocompare already showing benefit of investment

Esure has set aggressive targets in growing gocompare, and the company aims to more than double pre-tax earnings 2014 to £50m by 2020. The first nine months of ownership has been a success, and FY15 gocompare earnings of £23m (esure’s share of earnings £20m) were 12% ahead of our estimates. Indeed, the FY15 actual gocompare earnings were already ahead of our previous FY16 estimate of £22.5m. Furthermore, the company believes it can grow earnings in 2016 by 20-30%, suggesting £28 to £30m of earnings.

11:45 am
BE

This is an epit note. I'm going to skip a bit because this heading jumped out at me.

BE

Why do insurers own price comparison websites

Admiral started the first price comparison website in the UK in 2002, primarily as a tool to drive the creation of an internet-based distribution channel for motor insurance, and Admiral built its core motor underwriting business around this distribution channel. The success of the PCWs in increasing their penetration of new motor policies from 24% in 2007 to 70% in 2014 was the key driver in Admiral’s own success. Indeed, Admiral has invested in PCWs in Spain (Rastreator.com), France (LeLynx.fr) and the US (compare.com) in order to build an internet distribution channel in these markets and again hopes the development of this market will allow it to successfully grow its core underwriting business in these geographies. Rastreator.com and LeLynx.fr are already profitable (£2m of combined earnings in 2015), although this has been offset by a £22m loss / investment in its US compare.com franchise. Esure sponsored gocompare for similar reasons. We believe it will be in the insurers’ best interest to diversity away from motor insurance, in order to build deeper customer relationships and to lever advertising spend over a larger offering.

Neither Admiral nor esure get any benefit in terms of data or preferred access, as the businesses are run at arm’s length. However, it is valuable for them to have one of the big four, as it protects them from the PCWs introducing a price increase for lead generation at the insurers’ expense, and it also protects the distribution market from a PCW sacrificing volumes for growth. Although the primary reason for the insurers to own the PCWs is to ensure the success of the channel as a distribution channel, we do believe Admiral and esure will look to maximize their investments and follow the lead of Moneysupermarket and diversify away from insurance and particularly motor insurance into other areas of price comparison. Home insurance is a key potential growth market for both Admiral and esure, and therefore likely a focus for both confused and gocompare to lead the increase in home insurance penetration through PCWs towards the level of motor insurance.

PM

Exploring scenarios for a combined entity
Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) is often the subject of M&A speculation – a perennial hot topic in the auto sector. Although CEO Sergio Marchionne has publicly expressed his preference for other potential combinations (CNBC interview, 30 March 2016), in this report we explore in detail what a merger with PSA might look like. We think the companies complement each other well in terms of regional mix, and at the same time see significant potential for synergies (large overlap in products and general R&D). A merger would create a group of much greater scale (#5 car producer globally by market share, #2 in Europe and #1 in Latam) and better regional diversification. We also look at an alliance, which offers slightly less (but still significant) synergy potential.

PM

This is UBS

PM

€2.3-5.3bn synergies after full integration, c45-130% FCA share price upside
We estimate that a merger could yield annual synergies of €2.3-5.3bn (€1.9-4.1bn in an alliance), equivalent to c25-60% of combined 2017E EBIT. These synergies derive from combining production plants and model platforms, as well as from savings in general R&D, overhead and procurement costs. Based on our NPV model, a merger could add €2.9-8.0/share in value for FCA shareholders, implying c45-130% potential upside to the current share price, and based on a 50/50 share/cash acquisition of PSA by FCA at a 20% premium to PSA's current market value. We've developed an interactive merger model to enable investors to flex all the assumptions that went into our modelling.

PM

Significant execution challenges
Our merger scenarios assume plant closures, platform consolidation, R&D rationalisation and overhead optimisation, all of which may face political and regional challenges due to the re-allocation of resources they would involve. Nevertheless, even in a conservative scenario and assuming no plant closures, an FCA/PSA combination would still be value-accretive, which just serves to demonstrate how economies of scale play out in the auto industry.

Valuation: Merger scenario not reflected in our price target; Neutral
As the likelihood and timing of any merger are unpredictable, we continue to value FCA on a stand-alone basis. We maintain our Neutral rating and €7 SOTP-based price target. On a stand-alone basis, we have a cautious longer-term stance on FCA due to its relatively weak balance sheet and strong earnings exposure to the US trucks/SUV segment, which is at a cyclical high.

BE

We see the
market is pricing-in zero for Drax’s coal-fired units, and any small change would be a small
incremental positive for the asset lives and optionality value.
Comment
 To recall, in November 2015, Amber Rudd, Energy Secretary, said she would set out proposals to
close coal by 2025 and restrict use from 2023. Our understanding is that the UK Government has
been due to publish a consultation by spring. But it was put back to May (after changes to the
capacity market consultations took priority) and the Independent has been back due to lobbying
form the coal-fired industry.
 The government has removed large-scale support for CCS (e.g. for the White Rose and Peterhead
projects) that involve piping CO2 gas out to depleted North Sea fields. But, there are other forms of
carbon capture and storage. For example, Engie has long had small schemes attached to some of
its lignite plants in Australia (a few MWs).
 Our view is that any rule to close coal-fired plants after 2023 is superfluous to the existing
measures. The limitations from the Industrial Emissions Directive (milestones in 2020 and 2023), the CO2 tax, and age of the coal-fired plants all will work to close coal. NOX, SO2 and particulate emission constraint regulations beyond the IED in 2023 would do work to cause a shift away from coal. Likely Drax’s units (the most-efficient) will be the only coal-fired assets left, and they will only be running winter peakload at that time.
 We note that most gas is running ahead of coal in the UK merit order. The GB capacity auction and black start contracts will keep much of the existing fleet open, and ensure security of supply for
winter. However, the UK Government will likely acknowledge that they need either new-build gas- fired generation or biomass-conversions to bridge the transition to a zero-carbon world, in our view.

BE

Action
We see Drax (TP 325p, Outperform) as the clearest possible play on coal-fired regulation. The business has three coal-fired units that we (and the share price) reflect zero value for. The commodity price curves and CO2 taxes make these units marginally uneconomic. Small movements in gas prices or scarcity pricing in GB power can bring these units very high earnings leverage. The assets are at the worst point of the cycle.

Recent events highlight a widening gulf between Mike Ashley's long-
term vision and growing governance concerns in the City. We believe the
shares currently price in an over-pessimistic outlook, and Mr Ashley should
consider taking SPD private given the group's free cashflow generation and
underleveraged B/S. PT cut to 550p but we stay on Buy.
A torrid start to 2016 has come with a warning from SPD in response to weak sales in
the closing stages of 2015. We have cut estimates by 7% for this year to reflect that. We
downgrade longer term estimates by 14%/18% as we recognise UK retail operations have
reached a margin peak. Still, a 9x cal 2017 P/E confirms just how under water sentiment is.
Our price checks provide some encouragement at a time when investors are
understandably debating whether the combination of slowing sales and gross margin
expansion indicates mgmt. has been protecting profits at the detriment of the customer
offering. In the UK we have found SPD to have maintained a strong lead on pricing in third
party brands relative to other scale retailers. And while the discount positioning of owned
brands vs. external ones has eroded a little in the past two years, it continues to represent
a compelling trading down option in SPD stores.

BE

A few factors should underpin a return to MSD growth from 16/17E as we
speculate on the potential for international margins to have troughed in 15/16E, and the
extent to which a foray into the discount gym segment can provide an alternative source of
profits in the UK in coming years. At this juncture we assume only limited success in SPD's
efforts to better position itself at the fashion end of the market despite recognising the capex
requirements of shifting the store portfolio to a mix more conducive to a wider customer
audience.

BE

And finally Mr. Ashley's take private option looks compelling here as the £1.48bn
of required capital needed for a 550p take out compares with SPD's adjusted net debt/
EBITDAR of 1.3x and expected cumulative freecashflow of greater than £700m in the next three years.
The business could repay c.40% of that capital requirement with two years of freecashflow
and the cash raised from selling its JD Sports stake (before even considering utilising SPD's
own B/S to raise more funds).
